Literature Review: The spin Seebeck effect (SSE) has emerged as a pivotal phenomenon in the field of spintronics, offering a novel method to generate and detect spin currents in magnetic materials through the application of a temperature gradient. Since its initial discovery in 2008, the SSE has been the subject of extensive research aimed at understanding its underlying mechanisms and exploring its potential applications. This literature review focuses on the role of the SSE as a sensitive probe for investigating elementary excitations, spin correlations, transport properties, magnetic order, and domains in solids, as well as its implications for the emerging field of nuclear spintronics. The SSE manifests across a broad spectrum of magnetic materials, including ferro-, ferri-, and antiferromagnets, as well as paramagnets characterized by classical or quantum spin fluctuations. The voltage generated by the SSE provides valuable insights into the fundamental properties of magnets, such as the nature of elementary excitations, the configuration of static magnetic order, the extent of spin correlations, and the mechanisms of spin transport. Recent studies have highlighted the versatility of the SSE in probing these properties, underscoring its significance in advancing our understanding of magnetic materials. For instance, the SSE has been utilized to investigate the magnon spectrum in ferromagnetic insulators, revealing the role of magnon-driven spin currents in the generation of the SSE voltage. Furthermore, the SSE has been employed to explore the spin correlation lengths in antiferromagnetic materials, offering a new perspective on the dynamics of spin transport in these systems. The discovery of the nuclear SSE has opened up new avenues for research in nuclear spintronics, where the focus is on the manipulation and detection of nuclear spin currents. This phenomenon extends the concept of the SSE to the nuclear spin system, providing a unique tool for studying nuclear magnetic properties and their interaction with electronic spins. The integration of the SSE with the inverse spin Hall effect has facilitated the electrical detection of spin currents, enhancing the sensitivity and applicability of SSE-based measurements. This synergy has enabled the characterization of spin transport properties in various materials, including metals, semiconductors, and insulators, thereby broadening the scope of spintronics research. In conclusion, the SSE represents a powerful and versatile probe for investigating the magnetic properties of solids, with significant implications for the development of spintronic devices and the exploration of novel magnetic phenomena. The ongoing research on the SSE and its applications in spintronics continues to uncover new insights into the complex interplay between spin, charge, and heat in magnetic materials, paving the way for future advancements in this exciting field.
